item.content: The Usual Suspects is an accomplished synthesis of noir elements and, as such, is an entertaining entry to the genre.

item.content: After following the beckoning twists and turns, you're left trapped and more than a little disappointed for getting in so deep.

item.label: fresh
item.content: After I first saw the film, I recommended it to people as an entertaining and commercial crime thriller; a standard story done very well. And then I saw it again. The movie is so much better the second time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The twist at the end is a corker, but crucial questions remain unanswered. What's interesting, though, is how little this intrudes on our enjoyment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Director Bryan Singer gives his film enough surface flash to entertain future late-night cable possibilities.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As entertainment, the film is a lukewarm experience. But as a piece of construction, The Usual Suspects is a slick bit of business.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lots of fun and a very handsome, widescreen production by director Bryan Singer, who co-wrote the original script with once-and-future partner (and ex-private detective) Christopher McQuarrie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Once again, my comprehension began to slip, and finally I wrote down: 'To the degree that I do understand, I don't care.'

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dense with plot intricacies, thick with atmosphere, and packed with showy roles for a hip ensemble, The Usual Suspects is fun to watch -- a celebration of cool actors having a good time playing sweaty and devious lowlifes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Slips on the banana peel of exaggerated fear factor, falling facedown with the introduction of an uber-creep serial killer (Ben Kingsley) grimly stalking some hapless prey.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [A] visually jarring, psychologically daring trip that explores terror in a fresh, if crazy, manner.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Its junkiness shines through its posh patina. Exploitation is just no fun anymore, now that it's all so damn tasteful.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A grisly, depraved and wholly uninvolving exercise in empty mannerism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Suspect Zero is that rare case of a dull idea redeemed by sharp talent.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A violent, depressing and often ridiculous waste of time.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Merely adequate.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The kind of by-the- numbers psychological/ action thriller that Paramount Pictures routinely makes with Ashley Judd and Morgan Freeman.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Suspect Zero is intriguing enough to be worth deciphering. It just delivers zero scares.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is a black hole of failed ambition that mystifies on every level and offers zero payoff.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The latest evidence that Hollywood has run the se rial-killer thriller into the ground through overuse.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unless this is your first serial-killer movie, you've no doubt seen it all before.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [A] pretentiously made and excruciatingly dull thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Suspect Zero may be nonsense but at least it's not bland nonsense.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Suspect Zero knows from creepy . . . and compelling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A gussied-up bore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all its trying, Suspect Zero ultimately fails to hit home. It falls somewhere between a genre picture and arty exploration of big themes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Too devised and elaborate to really engage us.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie isn't talking to us, it's talking to other serial killer movies.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Alfred Hitchcock's trademarked cinematic development of suspenseful drama, through mental emotions of the story principals, is vividly displayed in Suspicion.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite a silly cop-out ending (imposed by RKO), a gripping domestic thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Hitchcock is probably the most artful sophist working for the films -- and anyone who doesn't think so should see Suspicion.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A movie that makes sense only to the eye (and even then . . .).

item.label: fresh
item.content: Argento works so hard for his effects -- throwing around shock cuts, colored lights, and peculiar camera angles -- that it would be impolite not to be a little frightened.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's always fascinating to watch; the thrills and spills are so classy and fast that the movie becomes in effect what horror movies seemed like when you were too young to get in to see them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Argento's methods make potentially stomach-turning material more interesting than it ought to be.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film is too lazy to provide any actual jokes with its send-up of the genre.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Short on thrills and laughs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Craven tries to do this 'veggie-man' horror in a suitable DC Comics style; and with Louis Jourdan as arch-villain 'Arcane', not to mention Adrienne Barbeau (Mrs John Carpenter) as the Thing's object of desire, he's definitely on the right track.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of those movies that fall somewhere between buried treasures and guilty pleasures.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [The film] wants desperately to be funny and, from time to time, it is. However, you might wish it would trust the audience to discover the humor for itself.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As summer shoot-'em-ups go, this is pretty well executed, with plenty of macho posing and gunfire.

item.label: rotten
item.content: he high definition SWAT training footage resembles a US Army recruitment ad, appropriate since TV journeyman Johnson imagines downtown LA as an unpatrolled Baghdad, swarming with guntotin' mercenaries pursuing their share of the bounty.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There is something sneakily gratifying about all this.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A rigmarole of stranded cliches and thrill-free action-movie legerdemain.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You can't get mad at it -- except for the two hours of your life it steals from you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The director, a TV guy named Clark Johnson, doesn't shoot action very well, which is sort of a handicap.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Director Clark Johnson strives for realistic detail and action. Unfortunately, such adherence to technical purity proves to be a weakness for the movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: S.W.A.T. has blockbuster ambitions, but it develops characters and plot at a leisurely pace better suited to the small screen than the big one.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As summer popcorn movies go, you could do worse than S.W.A.T.

item.label: rotten
item.content: SWAT is better than Gigli, but so is most outpatient surgery.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite the usual macho posturing and testosterone poisoning that are the hallmarks of such projects, S.W.A.T. finds some room for a comfortable lived-in quality among a small, likable cast that exudes terrific chemistry.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What we have here is a model for the paint-by -numbers, perfectly generic, proudly soulless summer action flick.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A worn-out yawner of a cop thriller where even the cliches seem to realize how dated they are.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Schlocky, slam-bang fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A lifeless trudge through squandered opportunities and god-awful dialogue.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Fresher popcorn than most of the sequels that have come and gone.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A film full of phony swagger and dialogue so awful you hope for once-distracting conversations to break out in the theatre around you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: One of those generic cop-slash-war movies of the Jerry Bruckheimer school -- where men are men and so are the women, where the hardware is fetishized.

item.content: This is grand-scale studio-work at its most beguiling.

item.content: A considerable achievement even if, on balance, it's more of a Tim Burton phantasmagoria than a Sondheim fantasia.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie may substitute Grand Guignol for laughs at times, but it's spectacularly stylized -- each throat-slashing exceptional -- persuasively sung, and imaginatively adapted for the screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's as if Burton was born to direct it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A thoughtful, sincere and moving film, buttressed by a fine, central performance by an actor at the top of his form.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is grand-scale studio-work at its most beguiling.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is distinguished, hypnotic, brilliantly executed and positively electrifying.

item.label: fresh
item.content: 'Sweeney Todd': Burton has deconstructed and redefined Sondheim's masterwork, creating a film that compliments its stage predecessor. 'Todd' is at once different from the play and yet not different at all. A unique achievement

item.label: rotten
item.content: This Sweeney Todd is all subtext and no substance. It starts off large and swaggering but doesn't know where to turn next: Burton seems fixated on serving up an event, to the extent that he neglects to dig into the story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mesmerizing and highly entertaining.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's easily Burton's best since, well, ever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Stylized but spasmodic, this Sweeney seems more interested in distancing than captivating an audience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Depp may not be a trained singer, but his voice is more than passable, and his presence -- his Sweeney is Edward Scissorhands gone bad -- is perfect.

item.label: fresh
item.content: By all means go, and be prepared for a holiday musical like no other.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The wait for a good Tim Burton movie is finally over.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sondheim's original musical was already a mad synthesis of Jacobean shock, Brechtian irony and Dickensian pathos -- to which Burton's lush visuals add another layer of aesthetic distance. The overall effect is somewhere between melodrama and camp.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film benefits from Burton's consistency of vision. Swooping camera work and a sense of really discomfiting fantasy do the groundwork. When characters break into song, it fits in the world Burton has built.

item.label: fresh
item.content: No sentiment goes unbloodied in [Burton's] exuberantly dark Sweeney Todd.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An elegant horror film that takes pleasure in its own theatricality, gives pleasure with caustic wit, trusts the power of Stephen Sondheim's score and exults in flights of fancy that only a movie can provide.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It combines some of Tim Burton's favorite elements: The fantastic, the ghoulish, the bizarre, the unspeakable, the romantic and in Johnny Depp, he has an actor he has worked with since Edward Scissorhands and finds a perfect instrument.

item.content: This is one very tuneful labor of love.

item.content: The only reason to see this film is for the acting.

item.content: Sweet and Lowdown is undeniably pleasant, but British actress Samantha Morton quietly explodes it: Her performance is like nothing I've seen in recent years.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: If there's anything we can learn from the creatures here, it's that any day in which you don't get stripped of your coat or eaten by a bear is probably a good one.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There are audience rewards for sticking with the herd and its lonesome cowboys.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a gorgeous and, believe it or not, riveting documentary...about sheep.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It may not be your thing, but Sweetgrass is unlike anything you'll see in a theater this year. It bravely strays from the flock.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Filmmakers Ilisa Barbash and Lucien Castaing-Taylor rigorously follow the cinema-verite creed: no sonorous Morgan Freeman voiceovers, no explanatory intertitles until the finale, just carefully observed reality.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you're used to the ADD pace of modern filmmaking, Sweetgrass will probably drive you crazy. If you can adjust, it could widen your soul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sweetgrass is an unexpectedly intoxicating documentary, unexpected because it blends high artistic standards with the grueling reality of one of the toughest, most exhausting of work environments.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In an extraordinary series of tableaux that are alternately idyllic and severe, Sweetgrass defies the conventions of what most of us regard as a documentary film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Leaves behind the domain of ethnography and becomes a work of art.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The filmmakers' motivation couldn't be clearer: They needed to capture a way of life that may soon exist only on film and in memory.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An intriguing but overly demanding portrait of rural Montana that concentrates on sheep and their herders.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Castaing-Taylor's lensing -- from sheep staring into a camera to panoramic views of the gorgeous landscape -- is pleasing to the eye.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The first essential movie of this young year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the breathtaking vistas of Big Sky Country in Ilisa Barbash and Lucien Castaing-Taylor's unforgettable sheep-herding documentary come close to heaven, it's telling that AC/DC's \"Highway to Hell\" can be faintly heard.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Memorably captures a dying way of American life, a marvelously untrammeled American landscape and at least two animals -- men and sheep -- that despite their millennia-long domestic relationship still have a spark of wildness in them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As subcultural anthropology, it's unassailable. Yet the often ugly-looking DV aesthetic dilutes the cumulative effect.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sweetgrass showcases an elemental intimacy between man and animal.

item.content: The kind of flick that gives fluff a good name.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For the farce it so desperately wants to be, the film often feels slack and too reliant on so-so punch lines for laughs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You go to America's Sweethearts anticipating a prime flossy, glossy entertainment. You come away better by a few laughs but with expectations sadly deflated.

item.content: It's as preposterous and phony as a Confederate C-note, but Reese Witherspoon has so much natural beauty, talent and charm she guarantees more fun than the day the hogs ate Willie.

item.content: Despite her relentless vim and winsome facial symmetry, Witherspoon is just too dialed-up to be America's Sweetheart.

item.content: It is definitely worth seeing.

item.content: If you're a fan of Witherspoon, this movie was produced, shot, edited and distributed entirely for you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sweet Home Alabama is the latest picture to give you the sense that Hollywood filmmakers simply plucked another old pop-tune title ripe for ripping off, then were shaken by the rude reality of coming up with a script to jerry-build around it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Reese Witherspoon makes the proverbial silk purse out of a sow's ear in the romantic comedy Sweet Home Alabama, demonstrating how even the most mediocre of material can be redeemed by a convincing performance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pure formula, right down to Melanie's final choice, which will come as no surprise to anyone paying attention.

item.content: This is a feel-good movie that does just that.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sweet Home Alabama may be sweet and small and inconsequential, but it offers the privileged experience of watching two stars being born.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you can tolerate the redneck-versus-blueblood cliches that the film trades in, Sweet Home Alabama is diverting in the manner of Jeff Foxworthy's stand-up act.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I didn't mind when Reese Witherspoon dyed her career Legally Blonde, but I found it downright disappointing to watch it go south in Sweet Home Alabama.

item.content: A movie with a more sitcomic premise you are unlikely to find.

item.content: As predictable as a Florida election controversy, as wholly amusing as a cold plate of grits.

item.content: Essentially a string of gags loosely looped together, a set of absurd situations for the actors to clown their way through, Talladega Nights is an affable entertainment, both a celebration and a satire of lowbrow pleasures.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Talladega Nights may be brash, unbridled, even unhinged, but its cornpone humor is rich in parody, and its craftsmanship is superb.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the movie about a moronic NASCAR racer overall is uneven and Ricky Bobby's saga lacks focus, the stupid-comical banter and the lampooning of this particular brand of car racing proves entertaining.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ferrell and his writing partner Adam McKay (who also directs, as he did Anchorman) are utterly without shame in their eagerness to recycle old ideas. This pair could make a blue box jealous.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The hilarious everyman riffs and contagious fun are reason enough to fuel up on such a wonderfully throwaway gag-fest.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Talladega Nights is very funny at times, even if the Ballad part mostly boils down to a series of comedy sketches connected by a recurring character.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The picture gets a bit long near the finish. But comedies live and die on the basis of their laugh quotient, and Talladega Nights gets its share.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The laughs come and go, but Ferrell makes NASCAR his bitch funny. Funnier. And more fun. And then the fun skids to a stop.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ferrell reteams with director Adam McKay (Anchorman) for another gleefully trashy comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Whoo, mama: Will Ferrell and NASCAR do make a purty pair. They go together like peanut butter and fried bananas in Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby.

item.label: fresh
item.content: 'What does diablo mean?' 'It's like Spanish for fighting chicken.' If you cracked so much as a shell of a smile reading that, then run, don't walk, to see Talladega Nights, where you will get an entire year's worth of equally irresistible nonsense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you can delight in the delight of others, you just may delight in this. Otherwise, prepare to be awfully jealous, because it's the sort of picture where the actors are having a lot more fun than the audience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Talladega is the first comedy this year to make me laugh so hard I snorted.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby is perfectly stupid chuckleheaded bliss, an achievement of the lowest and highest order. Every week should hold a movie like this.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's a whiff of desperation behind the comic romp Tamara Drewe that gives it some unexpected sting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This screen adaptation by director Stephen Frears successfully re-creates the strip's pastoral tone and cheeky humor.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film lacks Frears' usual master touch; it often feels flat and self-conscious, in a way that the book never does.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While no one would celebrate Tamara Drewe as a great movie, it is a reliable dispenser of visual and erotic pleasures.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You know where you're going in territory that's actually more Jane Austen than Hardy, but Frears makes the most of the many bumps and twists.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Caught midway between literary genres, the film lacks the literary sheen of Hardy and the darker comic impulses of Simmonds.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Erotic comedies are often attempted but rarely realized. Tamara Drewe is proof that sexy and funny need not be mutually exclusive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tamara Drewe is one in a million.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bucolic romp set in a strikingly picturesque spot in England's Dorset County, it has its moments of charm. But the clever comedy it promises never really materializes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Go through your mental checklist of what you want in a romantic comedy-drama: novel plotting, characters to care about, witty dialogue, bull's-eye casting, nimble direction, green and pleasant locales, a lack of falling-in-love montages.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Here and there, tentatively, Frears and his design team approximate the pictorial flourishes of the graphic novel. But the ensemble appears to be guessing, much of the time, at a proper performance pitch.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tamara Drewe is one of those British comedies in which, one way or another, we envy all of the characters -- even, briefly, the one run over by stampeding cows.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Don't let the English accents fool you - the characters are as thin as cartoons.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Tamara Drewe is a frolic that keeps tripping over its own gorgeous feet.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's not even any biting satire on social mores or anything else. The laughs are as broad as the scenery is picturesque. The characters are types but the whole experience is agreeable enough.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: I surrendered midway through to the film, to the wayward torque of its plot and the near-perfect pitch of its acting ensemble.

item.label: fresh

item.content: Tamara Drewe makes a strong case for rhinoplasty, and a stronger one for the pleasures of comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If \"Tangled\" hasn't morphed into a Broadway show within five years, then Disney isn't as smart as I think it is.

item.content: The result is a bracing film that's halfway between a string of MTV videos (Courtney Love put together the edgy soundtrack) and some of that network's over-the-top cartoons.

item.content: One of those chew-the-popcorn, munch-the-candy flicks - - the kind you go into expecting to have a good time, but nothing more. Given those expectations, disappointment is as unlikely as boredom.

item.content: I walked into the theatre hoping for a nice evening and came out as a hard-line Marxist, my head a whirl of closets, delusions, and blunt-clawed cattiness. All the film lacks is a subtitle: The Lying, the Bitch, and the Wardrobe.

item.content: It's just that there's been an altitude adjustment -- fewer stilettos, more flats. Ask what women want of a chick flick and one answer may be this -- a pleasant reunion with cherished friends. Ask what women deserve and the answer is better.

item.content: Biting down on his pipe, his shirt collar permanently askew, Hopkins assays another concerted study in English repression -- a condition unexpectedly relieved by Winger's brash intelligence and brittle wit.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sharks have it bad enough as endangered, misunderstood predators with a terrible public relations image without seeing their serial-killing stardom drowned out by hammy acting and torture-porn villainy.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: The very idea of handing him over to professional lad Guy Ritchie, to be played as a punch-throwing quipster by Robert Downey Jr., is so profoundly stupid one can only step back in dismay.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Downey never winks -- hea(TM)s too much of a pro for that -- but like the man hea(TM)s playing, hea(TM)s much, much smarter than the movie hea(TM)s in.

item.label: fresh
item.content: By now we've seen so many good, bad, and indifferent Sherlocks that it's almost a relief to get something different, however wrongheaded. And there's no such thing as too much Downey.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Playing literature's greatest detective as a sort of self-loathing action hero, Downey has an absolute blast. And thanks to his performance in Sherlock Holmes, so do we.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dazzling visuals and hipster dialogue, but a story that stays true to the original source material.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a swashbuckling, pratfalling romp designed to make cerebral Holmes purists drop their monocles into their teacups.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though purists may balk at Arthur Conan Doyle's literary world being manhandled into a blockbuster by never-subtle director Guy Ritchie, Downey has a winning take on Holmes: He's always on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What is surprising is how bland the results are. The explosions and action sequences have an odd cheapness to them and the central plot is one of those dreary take-over-the-world routines.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At times, Ritchie and company try so hard to make sure this isn't your father's Sherlock Holmes that it comes across as, well, cartoonish.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is rip-roaring action-adventure of high order, a sometimes dizzying but ultimately thrilling display of showmanship on the part of the actors, director and screenwriters.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It seems that an evil aristocrat, executed for a series of murders, returns from the dead to mobilize an ancient secret society that he may have time-traveled into a Dan Brown novel to learn about. Doesn't that sound fascinating? I thought not.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Guy Ritchie is the worst screenwriter in the world, but, to be fair, he is not the worst director. He is only the worst director of the people who actually get to make movies.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The game is not afoot.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's complete trash and makes a mockery of Holmes's vaunted deductive reasoning.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Downey's career is something of a game of shadows, but it's one still worth playing, for now.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Downey and Law remain this presumptive franchise's draw.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What this film really celebrates is crunch-and-thud video-game-style action, not especially well choreographed by director Guy Ritchie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It doesn't take a master of deduction to see that Ritchie has decided to play it too safe with this sequel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In an act of criminal negligence, Ritchie has wasted Robert Downey Jr. in a sequel that eliminates smarts in favor of relentless headbanging.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Downey may think this interpretation is an insight, or funny, but it pushes what was already a rude rewriting of the classic characters into eye-rolling camp. And it throws everything off balance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I was let down by this loud and flashy but utterly empty sequel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie wants to be a horse but, even measured in box-office millions, it's just another nag.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Something of an overlong, overblown, disorganized mess, despite being slightly better than its predecessor.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The skill level in the script is elementary school, my dear Watson.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's nothing here but wreckage. \"Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows\" is so ineptly made that the story is advanced solely through announcements.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As Johnny Depp has done so brilliantly with his devilish Jack Sparrow, Downey has made this sly sardonic Sherlock stylistically all his own. Case closed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The game is now afoot with Holmes' arch-nemesis, Professor James Moriarity -- and that makes a notable difference. This time, Holmes is up against an equal, and it's elementary indeed that muscle and firepower alone won't carry the day.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This new outing matches the original Sherlock in wit, action and the bromance between Robert Downey Jr. and Jude Law.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Diminishing returns\" is a description that applies to many film series. \"Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows\" is a delicious exception.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the focus occasionally strays, the film emerges as a fascinating exploration and powerful indictment of a pressing national problem. This is Moore's biggest, best and most impassioned work.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One may quibble with Mr. Moore's anecdotal oversimplifications and his xenophilic fantasies, but he has struck a socio-psychic nerve in the body politic, generating a feeling of outrage that seems to be reverberating in every theater.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a movie to see in a theater. It'a group experience. All through the show you'll hear people laughing, crying, muttering, cheering, sighing, swearing, and gasping. And at the end, chances are they'll be on their feet applauding.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sicko is worth seeing -- as long as the big grain of salt needed for it is put on more than just the popcorn.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even Moore's worst ideological enemies would be hard put to dispute the basic argument of his new film Sicko: The American health-care system is a sick joke and has been for a very long time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moore has finally made a moving, whimsical, infuriating film that won't just infuriate the right-wingers who've made a cottage industry out of hating him nor sing to the liberal choir who supports even his shadiest arguments.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sicko will scare people, and it probably should.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Who are we?\" might be a better (if less jazzy) title for Sicko, Michael Moore's two-hour meditation on the sickly qualities of American health care.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moore may play loose with the facts, but you don't have to believe every frame in the movie to come away thinking that the message in Sicko is not only worthwhile, it is also inarguable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Michael Moore's latest documentary-as-soapbox-vituperation is a damning, touching, darkly comical expose on the United States health-care system.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's doubtful even Michael Moore would claim Sicko as the last word on the subject. But it is a first word -- a very loud first word -- and while it may have been said better, at least Moore said it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moore could open a lot of eyes with Sicko but as the song says, we don't need another hero, especially one self-proclaimed.

item.content: Why then should anyone of sane disposition wish to see the film? Because it is still a love story, and a very touching one at that.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's not every film maker who credits special thanks to both Luis Bunuel and Dee Dee Ramone, but then Mr. Cox doesn't fit any recognizable mold.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though dark and harrowing, explicit and unsparing, the movie proves a riveting biography of these burnt-out icons and their iconoclastic half-decade.

item.content: Soderbergh is less interested in making statements than he is in skillfully fulfilling genre expectations.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A crafty teaser that presents itself as one kind of film before gradually evolving into another kind altogether. I, for one, enjoyed both enormously.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Side Effects is a cracking thriller that ranks amongst Soderbergh's best, featuring electric performances by Rooney Mara, Jude Law, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Channing Tatum.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Side Effects virtually demands a three-word review: Just see it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The main thing to keep in mind while watching Steven Soderbergh's playful new thriller is not to take the movie too seriously or else you'll feel betrayed by the end.

item.label: rotten

item.content: \"Side Effects\" does a nice job teasing current anxieties about depression, medical ethics and class striving with the classic thriller quandary of \"Who's playing whom?\"

item.label: fresh
item.content: [It] will both keep you on your toes and at the edge of your seat.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: In some ways the film is more traditional than you think it will be, becoming a psychological puzzle piece. But Soderbergh lays the puzzle out so neatly, you can't help but be engrossed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a gripping, maddening and thoroughly satisfying thriller, made with artfulness and integrity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If this does prove to be Soderbergh's final film - and I wouldn't hold my breath - he picked a heck of a one to go out on.

item.content: It is nice that Sidewalks reflects a younger, multiethnic New York, one in which not everybody is wealthy and middle-aged or older as Allen's New York increasingly was. But diversity is no substitute for quality.

item.content: This kind of sophistication-lite may go down well with many viewers right now, but Sidewalks of New York isn't much more than a student film made by a talented amateur who's in over his head.

item.content: Payne has made a movie for the same sorts of people, one with body and 'nose' and character that movie lovers will savor long after the credits have rolled.

item.content: This isn't the sort of road comedy we're used to seeing. Its humor is more likely to provoke smiles and light chuckles than guffaws.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's Cassavetes-style aimlessness (think of it as a West Coast Husbands) gets a jolt when each of the guys pairs up with a willing woman.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Much like Altman, Hal Ashby and Billy Wilder -- three filmmakers whose movies are celebrated for their naturalism, their humanism and their wicked, often merciless satire -- Payne makes films about ordinary people with their rumples and flaws left intact,

item.label: fresh
item.content: The acting is superb, from the free-spirited Oh to the compassionate Madsen to the irresponsible Church. The standout is Giamatti.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sideways, based on a fine novel by Rex Pickett, is at once a literate comedy, a subtle examination of grown-up romance and a touching study of friendship.

item.label: fresh
item.content: From its first minutes, maybe even from the credits, you know you are seeing something very special.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sideways is one of those films that's a bit too good to review: It strikes a unique tone, blends a bit of tall-tale fun with everyday life, and pretty much hits every note in your psyche.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sideways is neither effete nor snooty. It's a knowing, often-tender comedy about the plight of middle-aged men who aren't exactly living fast-track lives.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With each new film, Payne and Taylor plane the edges of their wit. Yet this growing maturity merely buffs their work; it's not dulled one bit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As character study, as exercise in American ambiance or, simply as an entertaining movie, Sideways triumphs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With Sideways, the director of Election and About Schmidt has cobbled together his most mature, complete effort to date, a film that utilizes his off-kilter sense of humor and his ability to construct believable characters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like a good wine, this movie has clarity, subtlety and a pleasant aftertaste.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's not a false note here, and the entire supporting cast -- Madsen, Oh, Church and Marylouise Burke as Miles's Mother -- is uniformly excellent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Giamatti is a comedic gem.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The lack of A-list talent is one of the many subtle charms of Sideways, a movie that finds universal appeal in the various urges and dilemmas of its characters while avoiding most road-movie cliches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Treasure of Sierra Madre is one of the best things Hollywood has done since it learned to talk; and the movie can take a place, without blushing, among the best ever made.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's a quite enjoyable yarn buried under the hollow laughter.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie has never really been about gold but about character, and Bogart fearlessly makes Fred C. Dobbs into a pathetic, frightened, selfish man -- so sick we would be tempted to pity him, if he were not so undeserving of pity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Greed, a despicable passion out of which other base ferments may spawn, is seldom treated in the movies with the frank and ironic contempt that is vividly manifested toward it in Treasure of Sierra Madre.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The characters here are probed and thoroughly penetrated, not through psychoanalysis but through a crucible of human conflict, action, gesture and expressive facial tones.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Individual sequences generate an eerie tension that's always deflated, creating a jarring stop-and-go rhythm, and the atmospheric trickery never strays beyond a lot of smoke and mirrors.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Shyamalan is technically a superb film-maker, for all that he's picked up most of his tricks from Spielberg and Hitchcock.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A refreshing summer movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Shyamalan wants to be the metaphysical poet of movies, but he's dangerously close to becoming its O. Henry.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The same old same old: dull and recycled, with no surprises.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is almost completely lacking in suspense, surprise and consistent emotional conviction.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sitting through the last reel (spoiler alert!) is significantly less charming than listening to a four-year-old with a taste for exaggeration recount his Halloween trip to the Haunted House.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Shyamalan fuses the fictional evidence of his extraterrestrials with the presumed righteousness of God in a way that will make no sense to anyone who has ever questioned either.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ultimately comes up short.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the most effective movies so far at capturing a jittery nation's case of the yips.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's fair to speculate whether Shyamalan's persistence in replicating the otherworldly formula of The Sixth Sense might not be a futile and self-defeating exercise.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Turns out to have few thoughts and no thrills.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Certainly works as The Birds disguised as Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One creep fest of a movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A heartfelt movie that deals more nakedly with [Shyamalan's] core concerns than any of his other Hollywood films, and it doubtlessly will deeply touch many people as well as frighten them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A complex story told with assurance and performed with quiet conviction, Signs smoothly and stylishly blends scares and substance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As a writer-director in his feature film effort, Mr. Herzog has failed to make his harried hero's case or his parable believable. Otherwise, his Signs of Life provides vivid signs of considerable talent and promise.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Hopkins' performance may be the film's bravura showpiece, but Foster's goes the whole distance, steadfast, controlled, heartbreakingly insightful, a fine addition to her gallery of characterizations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Foster's character, who is appealing, is dwarfed by the monsters she is after. I'd rather see her work on another case.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is the grandest guignol Hollywood has produced in years.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A pretty sharp new thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The juiciest part is Hopkins,' and he makes the most of it. Helped by some highly dramatic lighting, actor makes the role the personification of brilliant, hypnotic evil, and the screen jolts with electricity whenever he is on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An accomplished, effective, grisly, and exceptionally sick slasher film that I can't with any conscience recommend, because the purposes to which it places its considerable ingenuity are ultimately rather foul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Understandably, much has been made of Hopkins' hypnotic Lecter, but the laurels must go to Levine's killer, admirably devoid of camp overstatement, and to Foster, who evokes a vulnerable but pragmatic intelligence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a bona fide classic of its kind.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Silence of the Lambs is pop film making of a high order. It could well be the first big hit of the year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For all the unbridled savagery on display, what is shrewd, significant and finally hopeful about Silence of the Lambs is the way it proves that a movie can be mercilessly scary and mercifully humane at the same time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There is little doubt that the most memorable aspect of The Silence of the Lambs is Anthony Hopkins' incomparable performance as Lecter.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A smart, restrained entertainment, it doesn't splash around in blood and hysteria.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The popularity of Jonathan Demme's movie is likely to last as long as there is a market for being scared.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Adroitly directed by Jonathan Demme, it lurks about the exquisite edge of horror, before finally leaping into an unholy maw of bloody bones and self-awareness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Demme has created a supremely sensuous and hypnotic thriller, one that's likely to become his first major hit.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Poorly scripted by Akiva Goldsman, this murder mystery (helmed by Bruce Beresford) represents an awkward synthesis of autism and family abuse as social problems, failing to deliver suspense or excitement on any level.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Beresford draws the best from a fine cast. Only when he tries to up the thrill quotient near the end are the contrivances of Akiva Goldsman's debut script revealed, like cracks in the smooth surface of a frozen lake.

item.label: rotten
item.content: So predictable that you would almost swear you'd seen it before.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's the kind of picture that results when a film maker loses sight of the fact that a portion of his audience might actually think while watching a movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Silent Fall, a dramatically repressed psychodrama, could be sued for creative malpractice.

item.label: rotten
item.content: French director Christophe Gans's adaptation of the Silent Hill computer game is visually inspired and thematically ambitious, yet ultimately uninvolving.

item.content: Stuffed with cheap effects and devoid of tension, this French-Japanese-U.S. co-production contributes exactly zilch to the rich film history of those three nations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Silent Hill is mostly paralyzing in its vagueness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Structured around a series of blackouts and gross-outs, Silent Hill is one long free fall through icky surrealism and underlighted nightmares.

item.content: A great-looking but stupefyingly incoherent supernatural thriller,

item.content: Though Silent Hill's shoddy dialogue and incoherent story constantly irritate, several sights and scenes possess a certain surreal grandeur.

item.content: Too long by about a half hour, very much in love with its own excessive style, it still manages to be kinda creepy, at least when it stops taking its metaphysics too seriously.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The makers of the movie you're slogging through will spare no expense to demonstrate how much they hate us.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Christophe Gans' convoluted, overlong adaptation of the video game Silent Hill is the worst kind of horror movie: trash that takes itself seriously.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Silent Hill] works up a decent amount of solid, creep-show atmosphere in its first act before making some absurd decisions of its own in its second.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Let's start with the running time for Silent Hill: two hours and five minutes. Totally out of control.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not only can I not describe the plot of this movie, but I have a feeling the last scene reverses half of what I thought I knew (or didn't know).

item.label: rotten
item.content: In the end, Silent Hill degenerates into an overblown replay of all those Twilight Zone and Stephen King stories in which outsiders stumble upon a time-warped location from which there's no escape.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Witless, soulless and joyless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This one is dumber than a bag of coffin nails, despite the directing hand of Christophe Gans.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Silent Hill has plenty of bad acting, bad dialogue and a confusing plot -- all of which become exponentially more painful when the movie goes on forever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Revelation\" is incredibly boring as well as totally baffling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Demonstrates what half the budget and twice the story can do to turn a fake nightmare into a real chore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's never a good sign when the trailers playing before a film have richer, more complete narratives than the feature you've paid to see.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An ugly, assaultive collection of jump-scares.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Silent Hill is not a place you want to go, and that applies for moviegoers as well as this videogame adaptation's characters.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With horror altogether absent and a plot drowning in insipid convolutions, it's a film whose early warning to Heather should be heeded: \"Don't go to Silent Hill.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: A cheaper, cheesier sequel that's worse than its predecessor on every level (save being a half-hour shorter) and takes no special advantage of the stereoscopic process.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Only true devotees of the game are likely to recognize many of the figures on the screen, or care about a byzantine story stitched together from innumerable horror and fantasy shows.

item.content: Filmmakers Chris Kentis and Laura Lau ('Open Water') should have plugged the original's plot holes and straightened out its logic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's Olsen's performance that makes Sarah's plight matter. And the actress proves that her mesmerizing turn in last fall's Martha Marcy May Marlene -- about a woman on the lam from a cult -- wasn't a fluke.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Silent House feels like a psychotic episode come to life. It's impressive and oppressive, and it very effectively gets on your nerves.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Olsen is] terrific at showing shifts of emotion just underneath the skin of her wide, china-doll face.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Paranormal Activity has been here before, of course, but Silent House springs tangy new tricks, and Olsen is a primo scream queen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Olsen is compelling even when the film isn't.

item.content: The creeping presence of horror-flick hokum not only robs the scares of their strength, it shatters the realism that the single-take format is trying to convey.

item.content: Demonstrating the limits of being too clever in a genre movie, the art-house chiller \"Silent House\" lets the tenseness of its first act trickle away.

item.content: \"The silence will kill you!\" warn the posters for \"Silent House.\" That's only if the boredom doesn't get you first, though.

item.content: The facts it can lay its hands on do not support a politically alarming or dramatically compelling conclusion to the mysteries of this case. Nor do they lead to a very uplifting statement about the motives and character of its central figure.

item.content: Silkwood's 'ordinariness' protects her from being labelled a wild-eyed Trot, but that should not be allowed to obscure her courage or the whitewash ladled onto her story after her death.

item.content: Silkwood is the story of an ordinary woman, hard-working and passionate, funny and screwed-up, who made those people mad simply because she told the truth as she saw it and did what she thought was right.

item.content: Sayles' prolix narrative, weighed down with subplots and characters and canvassing many social ills, dilutes the impact of a work that should nevertheless still make an impact on thoughtful viewers.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: A crazy beaut of a comedy that brims with generosity and manages to circumvent predictability at every turn.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: This meaningful film keeps the laughs, giddy anxiousness and warm butterflies from the trailer and sustains it all through two full hours of a love story.

item.content: Lawrence, in her most high-low, sad-comic turn yet, is remarkable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It shouldn't work - there's just too much going on. But it does. Spectacularly. Go see it.

item.label: fresh

item.content: There's nothing wrong with the overrated Jennifer Lawrence that some serious acting lessons couldn't improve. The rest of the actors are pretty much on their own.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For a movie that seems at times to have no idea what it's trying to do, \"Silver Linings Playbook\" is compulsively watchable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sharp of tongue, generous of spirit, Silver Linings Playbook is a jagged, loopy romantic comedy about \"crazy\" people that insists, deep down, we're all a little nuts.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"The Silver Linings Playbook\" defies categorization: it's both comedy and drama, without fitting neatly into either genre.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Some movies are so likable, so naturally charming, that you'll forgive any dopey idea they throw at you.

item.label: fresh
item.content: David O. Russell has pulled off a tricky feat here, finding just the right tone in crafting a romantic comedy whose sweethearts suffer from bipolar disorder and depression.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Silver Linings Playbook isn't perfect - the ending is untidy - but it may just be the year's best comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A charming, witty, passionate romantic drama about a love transcending space and time, Somewhere In Time is an old-fashioned film in the best sense of that term.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Director Jeannot Szwarc strains hard for spectacular visual effects, though he's barely able to compose a competent close-up.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This must go down as a missed opportunity.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie surrounds its love story with such boring mumbo jumbo about time travel that we finally just don't care.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The [Grand H]otel and Mackinac [Island] are spectacularly lovely, but fail to give substance to this ephemeral endeavor.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though there is a near vaccuum at the center of the film, Sommersby is never boring, largely because of Ms. Foster's beautifully self-possessed presence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: From start to finish, it is a well-crafted film: part love story, part mystery, and all drama.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A square peg pounded into a round hole -- or, more exactly, a medieval European story that has been unsuccessfully updated to the period of the American Civil War.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's really an old-fashioned hankie-soaker with Gere and Foster ably jerking tears. An odd yet convincing couple, they won't replace Rhett and Scarlet, and frankly, my dears, who can? But belles wring and bosoms heave in a manner most pleasing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you're looking for a picturesque romance -- with a little intrigue on the side -- you could do worse than Sommersby.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This rather mushy combination of animation and live-action remains one of Disney's most controversial efforts.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Apparently the Disney wonder-workers are just a lot of conventional hacks when it comes to telling a story with actors instead of cartoons.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Better save this for nostalgia only -- kids won't be missing anything if they never encounter this relic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a good entry of its type.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Despite all the accepted props, from the lonely Southern plantation set in a miasmic bog to the squeaking bats and creaking coffins, this thriller is a pretty pallid offering.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The script is far from wonderful, and offers Siodmak little to get his teeth into, notwithstanding a beautifully atmospheric first entry for the Count (Chaney and coffin rising from the misty depths of a lake) and an effective finale.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Well mounted, nicely directed, and includes cast of capable artists.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A strangely literary and leisurely monster movie, laced with amusing gothic doodles.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The set, shot in a style reminiscent of the German Expressionist classics, is superb.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jennings is clearly having a wonderful time recreating the fantasies of his youth, but sometimes his perspective get a little too inbred, and the picture suffers for it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We cringe and laugh at -- and are ultimately moved by -- their clumsiness and innocence. And it endears us to the Rambo films in ways we never could have anticipated.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With apologies to Mr. Stallone, no one would ever argue First Blood was an essential part of any healthy childhood. But the ability to make-believe certainly is.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Son of Rambow is an inventive and amusing coming-of-age movie that deftly entwines elements of farce and fantasy, rebelliousness and sentiment, while paying seriously funny tribute to the transcendent power of art.

item.label: fresh
item.content: These two boys have, along with writer-director Garth Jennings, turned a coming-of-age story into a treatise on both the fragility of artistic vision and the danger of popular opinion.

item.label: fresh
item.content: After the movie, I imagined its writer-director, Garth Jennings (The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy) being more than a little like Will, and the movie uncannily similar to one of Will's comic epics.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sweet and sentimental, a bit racy to be a kids' film, a bit tame as grown-up entertainment, Son of Rambow is still a magical romp about childhood discovery and the birth of a lifelong love of the movies.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Son of Rambow is filled with small surprises and treasures, a veritable bounty of delight.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The rapport between the two rogue cineastes is enough to carry both films: the one they're making and the one Jennings is trying to make.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Milner and Poulter are a lot of fun to watch, a pair of first-timer naturals who don't reek of Dakota Fanning Young Actorliness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A joyous, touching story of friendship, mischief and imagination.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Few movies have captured the intoxicating effect of pop culture on kids better than Son of Rambow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I can't imagine a better movie for children and adults to enjoy together.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an absolute delight.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The kid-heavy cast tends to substitute enthusiasm for subtlety, but the way they throw their hearts into their games just makes it easier to get drawn in.

item.label: fresh
item.content: All part of growing up, an experience Son of Rambow portrays with genuine insight.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A noble effort, but it just kind of falls apart.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In the five years I've been co-hosting this show, this is the closest I've ever come to walking out halfway through the film, and now that I look back on the experience, I wish I had.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you are the son of Frankenstein, Flubber, Dracula, Lassie, Ali Baba, Sinbad, Billy the Kid, Davy Crockett, Robin Hood, Tarzan or Satan, you have to accept that the movie about you is likely not as good or memorable as the one about your dad.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A film top-heavy with joyless Tex Avery-style special effects and a dancing-baby bit embarrassingly reminiscent of TV's Ally McBeal.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With so many cuts a second, all attention goes into following the visuals. Just as well, since the story leaves so little to work with.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Guterman falls into the same trap he set for himself in the equally lifeless Cats and Dogs. There's nothing funny going on around those zany visuals.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's all very juvenile, yet there's a level of imagination one wouldn't expect from such fluff. It's the sort of visionary immaturity that bridges generations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Parents who let their kids see this stinker should be brought up on abuse charges; so should the movie ratings board that let this suggestive mess slip by with a PG rating.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What the filmmakers missed in assuming the mask from the earlier film is that it was Carrey's astonishing physical comedy that made that film a hit, not the animation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What we basically have here is a license for the filmmakers to do whatever they want to do with the special effects, while the plot, like Wile E. Coyote, keeps running into the wall.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's repetitious, overpowering and ultimately rather tiring, wearing out its welcome too soon. Plus, that darn baby just scares me.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's astonishing how dull a movie that packs so much visual overstimulation into its frames can be.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Son of the Mask is an irredeemable mess, a computer-animated Punch and Judy show without wit, heart or a single memorable performance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The attempt to invoke the imaginative mayhem of Warner Bros. animation never gets anywhere beyond the obvious effort, and it rests uneasily with the messages about the importance of being a good parent and balancing work and play.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unnecessary but not entirely unpleasant.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's not just an absence of Mr. Carrey that poses the problem. It's an absence of an intriguing story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Curdled gobs of antic shtick.

item.content: Sons and Lovers is a well-made and conscientious adaptation of D. H. Lawrence's famed novel, smoothly directed by Jack Cardiff and superbly acted by a notable cast.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A slack and superficial adaptation of Lawrence's novel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Somehow, this plainly euphemistic attitude toward Lawrence's fierce and fine account runs through the whole handsome picture and hobbles its real potential punch.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Astoundingly tedious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The picture is completely devoid of cinematic interest, adopting instead a tiresome theatrical aesthetic in which showy monologues are filmed in interminable, usually ill-chosen long takes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: By the end, the accumulated weight and lethargy of the production fails to invest Sophie's fate with the significance Styron achieves.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So perfectly cast and well-imagined that it just takes over and happens to you. It's quite an experience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though it's far from a flawless movie, Sophie's Choice is a unified and deeply affecting one. Thanks in large part to Miss Streep's bravura performance, it's a film that casts a powerful, uninterrupted spell.

item.content: A near-perfect commercial and cultural commodity.

item.content: What a feast for children! Long, and engrossing. Kids will love it! Wizard!

item.content: It offers more delights than disappointments -- and that qualifies as one of the year's great reliefs.

item.content: The filmmakers want to show us a magical world that is, at the same time, wholly believable. They want to create matter-of-fact miracles, but what they end up with is mostly just plain matter-of-fact.

item.content: [A] complete triumph...

item.content: Though the film will undoubtedly please the young viewers who flock to it, ultimately many of the book's readers may wish for a more magical incarnation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As a movie, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone has no inner life -- no pulse -- of its own: It's secondhand.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The magic mostly works.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If every movie that's greedily earmarked as a cinematic franchise could be as immaculately conceived as Chris Columbus' Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, there would be no reason to complain about the crass commercialization of films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Remarkably faithful, consistently entertaining if overlong adapatation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As it is, Harry's gotten a ride. But at a much lower altitude than his fans might have wished.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite the movie's pedestrian direction, our cranky old critic finds he can't deny kids the right to be enthralled.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie needs to be stronger dramatically, with a much more appealing central performance, to be the great family-oriented screen fantasy so many wanted.

item.label: fresh
item.content: During Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, I was pretty sure I was watching a classic, one that will be around for a long time, and make many generations of fans.

item.content: For every flight, the film serves up equal amounts of flattened-out shortfall.

item.content: The picture isn't inept, just inert.

item.content: Whenever it realizes it's venturing into truly risky territory, it bounces back to somewhere safer, like the terra firma of conventional boy-oriented teen-raunch comedy.

item.content: After being subjected to this painful movie ... you'll be rendered speechless. Not by any demonstrable good humor, but because of light brain damage.

item.content: None of this sounds promising and, indeed, the first half of Sorority Boys is as appalling as any 'comedy' to ever spill from a projector's lens.

item.content: The noble tradition of men in drag hits an all-time low in Sorority Boys, whose makers apparently believe that women's clothing can cover up any deficiency in acting, writing or direction.

item.content: Best left to the easily pleased.

item.content: Because the intelligence level of the characters must be low, very low, very very low, for the masquerade to work, the movie contains no wit, only labored gags.

item.content: Wolodarsky has made a film that even a rabid lowbrow like Homer Simpson (or, when the mood strikes, this critic) would find beneath his dignity.

item.content: Skip this dreck, rent Animal House and go back to the source.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even by the intentionally low standards of frat-boy humor, Sorority Boys is a bowser.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The situations and jokes are as predictable and as lowbrow as the endless pratfalls the boys take in their high heels.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Call me the sarcastic sister, but the only thing screaming in any convincing way here are the cheap look, epileptic direction, and off-key, \"edgy\" humor.

item.content: Sorority Row is an interminable mess of a film that juggles more characters and undeveloped subplots than it can handle and even manages to bungle the setup.

item.content: The tedious flick offers little more than a few scares, and plenty of boobs. And we're not just talking about the cast.

item.content: It lapses into that familiar category of movies that go in for lots of fancy obfuscation along the way only to make its story seem all the more simple, trite and contrived by the finish.

item.content: A booty-shakin', text-messagin', Facebook-referencin' multiplex moneyspinner for undemanding twenty-first-century teens.

item.content: Perhaps if you have a special interest in foul folks and morbidities, you will thrill to this Hal Wallis picture. Frankly, we squirmed -- and not from dread.
